pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.2: At that time Venerable Belaṭṭhasīsa, Venerable Ānanda’s preceptor, was staying in the wilderness.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.3: After walking for alms, he brought plain boiled rice back to the monastery, where he dried and stored it.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.4: Whenever he got hungry, he moistened it and ate it. As a consequence, he only re-entered the village for alms after a long time.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.6: “Why do you only re-enter the village for alms after such a long time?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.8: “But do you eat food that you’ve stored?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.10: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.11: “How can Venerable Belaṭṭhasīsa eat food that he has stored?” …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.12: “Is it true, Belaṭṭhasīsa, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.15: “… Belaṭṭhasīsa, how can you eat food that you have stored?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.16: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.17: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:1.18.1: ‘If a monk eats staple or non-staple food that he has stored, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.4: … The monk who has been given the full ordination by a unanimous Sangha through a legal procedure consisting of one motion and three announcements that is irreversible and fit to stand—this sort of monk is meant in this case.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.6: received today and eaten on the following day.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.8: apart from the five staple foods, the post-midday tonics, the seven-day tonics, and the lifetime tonics—the rest is called “non-staple food”.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.10: there are five kinds of staple food: cooked grain, porridge, flour, fish, and meat.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.11: If he receives staple or non-staple food with the intention of eating it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.1.12: For every mouthful, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.1: If it has been stored, and he perceives that it has, and he eats the staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.2: If it has been stored, but he is unsure of it, and he eats the staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.3: If it has been stored, but he does not perceive that it has, and he eats the staple or non-staple food, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.4: If he receives post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics, or lifetime tonics for the purpose of food, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.5: For every mouthful, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.6: If it has not been stored, but he perceives that it has, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.7: If it has not been stored, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.2.8: If it has not been stored, and he does not perceive that it has, there is no offense.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.2: if he stores and eats it during the right time;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.3: if he stores and eats post-midday tonics during the remainder of the day;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.4: if he stores and eats seven-day tonics during the seven-day period;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.5: if he uses lifetime tonics when there is a reason;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.7: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc38:2.3.8: The eighth rule, the training rule on storing, is finished.
